issues.description: The problem text explicitly requires the Farm to store "unique animals without duplicates" and to realize the aggregation using a Set implemented with a HashSet (Part 3 instructions). The solution implementation, however, declares the collection as a List<Animal> and initializes it as an ArrayList (solution_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Farm.java). This is a structural mismatch: a List allows duplicates while a HashSet enforces uniqueness. Students following the problem text (or tests expecting uniqueness) would be confused by the solution using a List and could be led to an incorrect final design.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the collection type consistent with the problem specification. Change the solution (and template guidance) to use a Set<Animal> (e.g., private Set<Animal> animals;) and initialize it in the no-argument constructor with new HashSet<>(); update getter/setter signatures accordingly. Alternatively, if the intended design is a List, update the problem statement (Part 3) to remove the requirement to use a Set/HashSet and clarify expected behavior regarding duplicates.

issues.description: The problem statement contains an internal contradiction about the Farm's collection type: the UML diagram shows the Farm attribute as "animals: List<Animal>" (UML lines), while the textual Part 3 instructions explicitly require using a Set/HashSet for unique animals. This conflicting guidance (UML vs. textual requirement) is likely to confuse students about which collection type to implement.
issues.suggested_fix: Resolve the contradiction in the problem statement: either (A) update the UML to show animals: Set<Animal> (and optionally indicate HashSet in notes), or (B) change the textual Part 3 instructions to accept a List and clarify how duplicates should be handled. Ensure the description, UML, and example/test expectations all consistently specify the same collection type and behavior (uniqueness vs. allowing duplicates).
